metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JavaScript For Loop
Loops can execute a block of code a number of times.
content.html: Loops can execute a block of code a number of times.

content.text: JavaScript Loops
Loops are handy, if you want to run the same code over and over again, each time with a different value.
content.html: Loops are handy, if you want to run the same code over and over again, each time with a different value.

content.text: Often this is the case when working with arrays:
content.html: Often this is the case when working with arrays:

content.code_html:
text += cars[0] + "<br>";
text += cars[1] + "<br>";
text += cars[2] + "<br>";
text += cars[3] + "<br>";
text += cars[4] + "<br>";
text += cars[5] + "<br>";

content.text: Different Kinds of Loops
JavaScript supports different kinds of loops:
content.html: JavaScript supports different kinds of loops:

content.text: The For Loop
The for statement creates a loop with 3 optional expressions:
content.html: The for statement creates a loop with 3 optional expressions:

content.code_html:
for (expression 1; expression 2; expression 3) {
  // code block to be executed
 }

content.text: Expression 1 is executed (one time) before the execution of the code block.
content.html: Expression 1 is executed (one time) before the execution of the code block.

content.text: Expression 2 defines the condition for executing the code block.
content.html: Expression 2 defines the condition for executing the code block.

content.text: Expression 3 is executed (every time) after the code block has been executed.
content.html: Expression 3 is executed (every time) after the code block has been executed.

content.code_html:
for (let i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
  text += "The number is " + i + "<br>";
}

content.text: From the example above, you can read:
content.html: From the example above, you can read:

content.text: Expression 1 sets a variable before the loop starts (let i = 0).
content.html: Expression 1 sets a variable before the loop starts (let i = 0).

content.text: Expression 2 defines the condition for the loop to run (i must be less than 5).
content.html: Expression 2 defines the condition for the loop to run (i must be less than 5).

content.text: Expression 3 increases a value (i++) each time the code block in the loop has been executed.
content.html: Expression 3 increases a value (i++) each time the code block in the loop has been executed.

content.text: How to use Expression 1
Expression 1 is used to initialize the variable(s) used in the loop (let i = 0).
content.html: Expression 1 is used to initialize the variable(s) used in the loop (let i = 0).

content.text: But, expression 1 is optional.
content.html: But, expression 1 is optional.

content.text: You can omit expression 1 when your values are set before the loop starts:
content.html: You can omit expression 1 when your values are set before the loop starts:

content.code_html:
let i = 2;
let len = cars.length;
let text = "";
for (; i < len; i++) {
  text += cars[i] + "<br>";
}

content.text: You can intiate many values in expression 1 (separated by comma):
content.html: You can intiate many values in expression 1 (separated by comma):

syntaxHighlighting.text:
for (i = 0, len = cars.length, text = ""; i < len; i++) {   text += cars[i] + "
"; }

content.code:
for (i = 0, len = cars.length, text = ""; i < len; i++) {   text += cars[i] + "
"; }

syntax_highlighting.text:
for (i = 0, len = cars.length, text = ""; i < len; i++) {   text += cars[i] + "
"; }

content.code_html:
for (i = 0, len = cars.length, text = ""; i < len; i++) {
  text += cars[i] + "<br>";
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
for (i = 0, len = cars.length, text = ""; i < len; i++) {   text += cars[i] + "
"; }

content.text: How to use Expression 2
Expression 2 is used to evaluate the condition of the initial variable (i < len).
content.html: Expression 2 is used to evaluate the condition of the initial variable (i < len).

content.text: But, expression 2 is also optional.
content.html: But, expression 2 is also optional.

content.text: If expression 2 returns true, the loop will start over again. If it returns false, the loop will end.
content.html: If expression 2 returns true, the loop will start over again. If it returns false, the loop will end.

content.text: Note
If you omit expression 2, you must provide a break inside the loop. Otherwise the loop will never end. This will crash your browser. Read about breaks in a later chapter of this tutorial.
content.html: If you omit expression 2, you must provide a break inside the loop. Otherwise the loop will never end. This will crash your browser. Read about breaks in a later chapter of this tutorial.

content.text: How to use Expression 3
Expression 3 increments the value of the initial variable (i++).
content.html: Expression 3 increments the value of the initial variable (i++).

content.text: But, expression 3 is also optional.
content.html: But, expression 3 is also optional.

content.text: Expression 3 can do anything like negative increment (i--), positive increment (i = i + 15), or anything else.
content.html: Expression 3 can do anything like negative increment (i--), positive increment (i = i + 15), or anything else.

content.text: Expression 3 can also be omitted (like when you increment your values inside the loop):
content.html: Expression 3 can also be omitted (like when you increment your values inside the loop):

content.code_html:
let i = 0;
let len = cars.length;
let text = "";
for (; i < len; ) {
  text += cars[i] + "<br>";
  i++;
}

content.text: Loop Scope
Using var in a loop:
content.html: Using var in a loop:

content.code_html:
var i = 5;

for (var i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
  // some code
}

// Here i is 10

content.text: Using let in a loop:
content.html: Using let in a loop:

content.code_html:
let i = 5;

for (let i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
  // some code
}

// Here i is 5

content.text: In the first example, using var , the variable declared in the loop redeclares the variable outside the loop.
content.html: In the first example, using var, the variable declared in the loop redeclares the variable outside the loop.

content.text: In the second example, using let , the variable declared in the loop does not redeclare the variable outside the loop.
content.html: In the second example, using let, the variable declared in the loop does not redeclare the variable outside the loop.

content.text: When let is used to declare the i variable in a loop, the i variable will only be visible within the loop.
content.html: When let is used to declare the i variable in a loop, the i variable will only be visible within the loop.

content.text: For/Of and For/In Loops
The for/in loop and the for/of loop are explained in the next chapter.
content.html: The for/in loop and the for/of loop are explained in the next chapter.

content.text: While Loops
The while loop and the do/while are explained in the next chapters.
content.html: The while loop and the do/while are explained in the next chapters.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Consider the following code: let i, x = ''; for (i = 0; i <= 5; i++) { x += i; } What will be the result of x ?
content.html:
Consider the following code:
let i, x = '';
for (i = 0; i <= 5; i++) {
  x += i;
}
What will be the result of x?
